title: (x) Karly "Dancemusic" album cover dotted geometric sans - Pinball {Mark S}
content:
I’ve been trying to figure out what font is used here for a few months now.  
I don’t have much to go on other than a friend’s suggestion of a font called “Fortuna Dot” that I’ve had no luck in finding.  
Any help’s appreciated.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [fontID.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080314221413/http:/typophile.com/files/fontID_3.jpg) | 107.61 KB |

 [‹ (x) Cacharel logo - similar to Sahara Bodoni {J. Edward Sanchez}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080314221413/http:/www.typophile.com/node/33895 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Serif face in Stockholm ad by Konst&Teknik - Swift {Hank} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080314221413/http:/www.typophile.com/node/33916 "Go to next forum topic")
author: soundboz

comments.content:
The letterforms aren’t identical, but you might be able to find a way to separate the dots from the background in [Budmo](http://web.archive.org/web/20080314221413/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/larabie/budmo/), by Ray Larabie. It might be as simple as nulling part of the letter in your graphics application.

I am guessing that the letters might have been from a film type (photolettering), that has not been digitized.

- Mike Yanega

BTW, the only ’Fortuna Dot’ I can find is [this one](http://web.archive.org/web/20080314221413/http:/www.dafont.com/fortuna-dot.font) by Harold Lohner, with three rows of dots.

- Mike Yanega
There is an old film font called Pinball that matches exactly, just as you suspected.

Yes, I see it in an old Letraset catalog, printed in 1991.

- Mike Yanega
